sections.title: Welcome to FRC Environment Setup
sections.content:
This module covers the essential setup steps for FRC development. Before you can start programming your robot, you need to install and configure the necessary tools and software. The setup process includes installing WPILib, configuring your development environment, creating projects, understanding the build system, and setting up the Driver Station.

For detailed step-by-step instructions, please refer to the WPILib Documentation: Zero to Robot Guide.

sections.title: What You'll Need
sections.subtitle: Essential components for FRC development:
items: Visual Studio Code: Recommended IDE with WPILib extension
Gradle Build System: Build automation tool (included with WPILib)
FRC Driver Station: Software for controlling and monitoring your robot
FRC Game Tools: Additional utilities for robot management

sections.title: WPILib Installation
sections.content:
WPILib (Worcester Polytechnic Institute Library) is the official programming framework for FRC robots. It provides libraries, tools, and templates for robot programming in Java, C++, and Python.

What's Included: WPILib installer includes the WPILib libraries, Java Development Kit (JDK), Gradle build system, Visual Studio Code with WPILib extension, and FRC utilities.

System Requirements: Windows 10/11, macOS 10.14+, or Linux (Ubuntu 18.04+). At least 5 GB free disk space required.

For detailed installation instructions, system requirements, and troubleshooting, please see the WPILib Documentation: WPILib Installation Guide.

sections.title: Creating Your First Robot Project
sections.content:
WPILib provides project templates that give you a starting point with the correct structure and configuration. Projects can be created using the WPILib VS Code extension, which ensures proper setup with all necessary files and dependencies.

Project Templates: WPILib offers TimedRobot (simple, beginner-friendly) and Command Robot (command-based framework, recommended for most teams) templates.

Project Structure: WPILib projects have a specific directory structure with source code in src/main/java/, configuration files at the root, and vendor dependencies in vendordeps/.

For detailed instructions on creating projects, understanding project structure, and configuring team numbers, please see the WPILib Documentation: Creating a Robot Program.

sections.title: Visual Studio Code Setup
sections.content:
Visual Studio Code (VS Code) is the recommended IDE for FRC programming. When installed with WPILib, it comes pre-configured with the WPILib extension, providing code editing, building, deploying, and debugging capabilities all in one place.

WPILib Extension: The extension adds FRC-specific features including project creation, code deployment, robot management tools, and IntelliSense for WPILib classes.

Key Features: Command Palette integration, integrated terminal, build tasks, code navigation, and Git integration make VS Code a powerful development environment for FRC.

For detailed VS Code setup, extension configuration, keyboard shortcuts, and workspace customization, please see the WPILib Documentation: VS Code Overview.

sections.title: Gradle Build System
sections.content:
Gradle is the build automation tool used by WPILib projects. It handles compiling your Java code, managing dependencies, and deploying code to the robot. Every WPILib project uses Gradle through the Gradle Wrapper, which ensures consistent builds across team members.

Key Concepts: The build.gradle file configures plugins, repositories, and dependencies. Gradle automatically downloads required libraries and manages vendor dependencies from CTRE, REV, and other vendors.

Common Tasks: Use ./gradlew build to compile your project and ./gradlew deploy to upload code to the robot.

For detailed information on Gradle configuration, managing dependencies, adding vendor libraries, and understanding the build lifecycle, please see the WPILib Documentation: Third-Party Libraries and Gradle.

sections.title: FRC Driver Station Setup
sections.content:
The FRC Driver Station is software that runs on your computer and communicates with your robot during matches and testing. It provides the interface for controlling robot modes, viewing robot status, and monitoring telemetry. The Driver Station is part of the FRC Game Tools package.

System Requirements: Windows 10 or higher with x86 CPU (ARM CPUs not supported due to LabVIEW dependency). Administrator access required for installation.

Key Features: Control robot modes (Disabled, Autonomous, Teleop, Test), monitor connection status, view telemetry and logs, configure joysticks/gamepads, display camera streams, and emergency stop functionality.

For detailed installation instructions, configuration, usage, and troubleshooting, please see the WPILib Documentation: Installing the FRC Game Tools and Driver Station Documentation.

sections.title: Setup Checklist
sections.subtitle: Complete these steps to get started:
items: Install WPILib using the official installer
Verify WPILib extension is installed in VS Code
Create your first robot project using the WPILib template
Configure your team number in the project
Install FRC Game Tools (including Driver Station)
Verify you can build and deploy code to your robot
Test Driver Station connection to your robot

sections.title: Getting Help
sections.content:
If you encounter issues during setup:

Official Documentation: The WPILib Documentation is your primary resource for setup, troubleshooting, and learning.

Community Support: Visit the Chief Delphi Forums for community help and discussions.

WPILib Support: Check the WPILib GitHub Issues for known issues and solutions.
